content: chose has always signified, in philosophy, that which doesn’t arrive > hupokeimenon or rēs, substance to which accidents happen, not only its accident
its very not-happening happens to the “Come” in its pas de chose, procès, as arrêt de mort that can’t be decided, neither life nor death
“in other words on living”: this “in other words” amasses powers of indecision & adds to utterance its capacity for skidding [see PAS]
contamination is not caused by contingency, contiguity, contagion but by chance
Derrida’s “translator’s note” [bottom band] as a double blind [Hillis Miller], blindly jealous double, double cortège
untranslatability will not stop the procession, cortège, over the border of another language, into the language of another
living on: reprieve, afterlife, “life after life,” life after death, more life or more than live > you’ll never have done w/ that suspension
translation as economy, write in a telegraphic style, telegraphics, telephonics, é-loignement, Ent-fernung
hymen or alliance in the language of the other, strange vow by which we are committed in a language not our mother tongue > Derrida’s committed, are you? translators?
it is impossible for living speech to speak on living [sur vivre?], unless it’s impossible only w/ living speech: aporia even more paralyzing
“What is life?” asks of its essence and its value
beginning as an attack [?] [Heidegger, philopolemology]
starting point: “no meaning can be determined out of context, but no context permits saturation” > structure of remnant/iteration (I have said this many other ways)
approaching edge of a text, lose sight of text and its outside, regular submerging of shore
pose question of bord, bord de mer, question of borderline preceding the determination of all dividing lines I just mentioned [i.e. the general bord before the contextual one?]
to approach a text it must have an edge [arêtes: edge, stop]
text overruns all the limits assigned to it, but I’m not trying to transform the world into a library by doing away w/ all boundaries, framework, all sharp edges (all arêtes)
text as differential network

what I still call “text” for strategic reasons, a differential network, a fabric of traces referring endlessly to something other than itself, to other differential traces, overruns its borders, all limits, everything set up in opposition to writing: speech, life, world, real, history, politics, economics
narrative of an event, event of narrative, narrative as the structure of an event

is the double affirmation triumphant or a paradoxical phase in work of mourning [re: Freud’s manic fantasy]? p. ~101 one never writes in one’s own language or in a  foreign language > derive all consequences of this, from each element: hence the triumph (necessarily double & equivocal, because also a phase of mourning)
quotation interrupts very belonging to which it is a necessary condition
how could we make a genre work w/out referring to it quotationally?
demand (mean English “demand”: request, order, petition) for a narrative [see p. 98 law]
literary studies in university don’t adequately explore problematic of judicial framing & jurisdiction of frames
Derrida relates little “sur” to surjet (overcasting) in La Dissémination
Blanchot’s Death Sentence, “title runs wild and drives the reader mad”
[The promise he doesn’t keep: anticipate translatable problems, see pp. 175-76]
scene of visibility: a primal scene > that which enables us to see should remain invisible, black, blinding [Plato]
performativity dissociated with the notion of presence [see p. 146]
“obsequent logic” in Glas
from polysemia (economy) to dissemination; p. ~93 from critical to deconstruction
difference btwn archeaology and eschatology as differance in apocalypse, that will be a while in coming
[re: tampering w/ ideal translatability & national language] a pedagogical institution can bear these 2 poles as long as nothing touches the borders of language
double affirmation: of death which triumphs over life, & triumph of life at edge of death
“there is no speech act not already the iteration of another”
possible from “first trace” on, which is why there is no first trace: the outside opens a pocket [cf. F p. xix crypt: pocket of resistance]
law = demand for story
impossible to tell which border forms the other, each comprehends the other by not comprehending the other > which one quotes the other?
“crisscross double invagination,” chiasma btwn double invagination possible because of iterability of the mark (folds coming from both borders)

double invagination constitutes story of stories, narrative of deconstruction in deconstruction: apparently outer edge of a clôture, makes no sign beyond itself, toward tout autre, w/out becoming dual, being “represented,” refolded, re-marked w/in the clôture > what the structure produces as an effect of interiority, this structure-effect is being deconstructed

one never writes in one’s own language or in a  foreign language > derive all consequences of this, from each element: hence the triumph (necessarily double & equivocal, because also a phase of mourning)
structure of invagination exposes precariousness of effects of “genre,” “mode, “corpus,” all historical fictions that certify its carte d’identité
relative synonymy Derrida seeks to produce btwn triumph of life & arrêt de mort
text lives on only if it lives on (sur-vit), it lives on only if it is at once (hama) translatable and untranslatable, Übersetzung and “translation” overcome

triumphant translation is a life after death, same goes for writing, trace, mark: neither lives nor dies, lives on, “starts” w/ living on (testament, iterability, restance, crypt, detachment that lifts the strictures of the “living” rectio or direction of “author” not drowned at edge of his text)

totally translatable disappears as body, writing, text, language; totally untranslatable dies immediately > thus, triumphant translation neither life nor death of text, only or already its living on, neither lives nor dies
[literary] title is not its own telos, not self-mirroring, writing prevents reflecting representation from folding back on itself
Blanchot’s narrative vs. narratorial voice
[extensive description] yes of event, yes of iteration, quotes, cites, in accordance w/ strange ring outside of presence, sur-vives
ring is sealed by arrêt de mort (syntax, almost untranslatable, is sealed in this French expression)
all organized narration, a matter for the police, narrative voice surpasses police investigation, if possible
writing as triumph of life
[Derrida does always affirm the word neutral, but here he seems to affirm Blanchot’s neutral] a neutral beyond dialectical contradiction and opposition
for Nietzsche, “writing should always mark triumph, Schreiben und Siegen-wollen, Nietzsche opposes this to dyspeptics for whom morsels get stuck in teeth [points to mors in Glas and “Fors”]
Derrida addresses his translators re: how any attempt at intertranslatability couldn’t fail to enter into translation

Blanchot: survivre, not living maintaining oneself, lifeless, in a state of pure supplement, movement of supplementing life, but stopping (arrêter) the dying, a stopping that doesn’t stop > speak on the arrête (ridge, cutting edge, backbone, fish bone, arris)
w/ Freud always un pas de plus et pas de thèse [re: speculation on death drive]

Derrida, pointing to confusions in Freud, worries that the reduction of double affirmation to Freud’s meaning of triumph (a narcissistic breaking of tie to destroyed object) would stain it w/ negativity of mourning, economic resenting, and melancholia [manic closer to melancholic than mourner]
sur, “on”, the entire enigma of “supplementary logic” [cf. GLAS p. 81r “sur” vs. “dans”]
survival & revenance, living on & returning from the dead: goes beyond life and death, supplementing each w/ sudden surge, a reprieve
work of mourning is thematic in Glas, “Pas,” “Fors”
acc. Freud, Verdikt (verdict, sentence, arrêt): “object no longer exists,” inspires ego to break tie (Bindung) to destroyed object, manic triumph of work of mourning [?]
Blanchot’s come, come, Derrida’s yes, yes
for Freud, triumph over mourning occurs w/ manic type, from Überwindung of normal success to Triumphieren of manic, how is this dissimulation possible?
Derrida refers to his deuil du deuil in “Ja ou le faux-bond” and his half-mourning
life being drawn through by sharp dividing line, edge where it is impossible to settle: arrête, angle of instability impossible to settle (s’arrêter)
via Hartman, is arrêt de mort “death sentence” or “suspension of death”?
the Il (who says “I”) donne la mort, he, the narrator (I), kills
arrêt de mort: decision on what can’t be decided—it also arrests death by suspending it: gives “living on”

crisis is the urgency, instant, of impossible decision (krinein, judgment is the impossible to reach), the suspensive arrêt suspends the decisive arrêt and vice versa > arrhythmic pulsation, imparts movement in stopping, never sure, unfortunately, fortunately
power of undecidability—another false name, rather than a pesudonym for difference, arrhythmic pulsation of the “word”
like death, arrêt remains undecidable, one arrêt marks delay, the other haste [2 syntaxes]

the suspensive arrêt arrests the decisive arrêt and vice versa, the arrêt de mort arrests the arrêt de mort, arrhythmic pulsation of title [Blanchot’s] before it scatters like sand, in stopping (s’arrêtant) (as arrêt), it gives movement, sets in motion [prime mover]
arrêt de mort as verdict
[compare crisis, event, instant, edge (arête) which gives momentum to Prime Mover]
suspensive arrêt already [déjà] undecided because it suspends, decisive arrêt undecided because what it decides, death, la Chose, the neuter, is undecidability itself
antagony from arrêt to arrêt, an Aufhebung that never lets up, arrêt arresting arrêt, both senses, both ways
judgment as that which is impossible to reach in each crisis, arrêt, decision
undecidable, neuter, death is the undecidable itself
death as undecidable itself
suspension that retains [Blanchot’s] title, compulsive pulsation of l’arrêt de mort, a decision that escapes the signature of any “I”
unreadable not opposite of readable but the ridge (arête) that sets in motion

arrêt arrests itself, stands, stays unstable, remains on arête of itself, it a-rests (for) itself, no consciousness, perception, no watchfulness can gather this remnance, no “I”, hence ghosts, fantasies, epochal pause

l’arrêt de mort, “ingenious” decision, one of those that are made (s’arrêtent) only in a language, escape signature by any “I”, untranslatable, decision is unreadable > unreadability does not arrest reading in face of opaque surface, it starts reading, writing, translating again
suspension that is a resurrection

I slice barbarously, illegitimately, as we always do, counting on implicit contract, impossible contract, that you’ve read “everything,” that you know the whole corpus by heart at every moment, w/ living heart that beats unceasingly (sans arrêt), w/out pulsation
suspension as resurrection
unreadability is absolute
infinite violence [of what’s strictly called] “double bind,” double invagination, double obligation, double demand > sans arrêt and arrêt de mort, no reconciliation
dream of a translation w/out remnants: a metalanguage, a guarantee

translation leaves behind an untranslated remnant, illegitimately, because it arrests the movement of the everyday possibility of literature and parasitism [see SPOM p. 135 translation causes ghost to drop into oblivion] [re: double syntax of arrêt de mort]
death, la mort—La Chose (itself as other)

temptation of exhaustive reading [of Shelly and Blanchot], recognize a “logic” that would enable us to read everything, in L’arrêt de mort and elsewhere, down to smallest grain of sand, letter [cf. GLAS p. 208r metal teeth reading machine] > a wager: I feel both the impossibility and possibility, each equally essential (same wager as translation w/out remnant)
in Blanchot’s L’arrêt de mort, there’s a 2nd death after resurrection [Lacan’s btwn 2 deaths]
vulgarity and foolishness inexcusable to Blanchot

death sentence, instant as elusive as last grain of sand in hourglass, death as result of dissemination of rhythm of life w/ no coup d’arrêt, unbordered/unbounded arrhythmy on beach that’s continuation of a sea: her pulse “scattered like sand”
the temptation of an exhaustive reading

reaffirmation, triumph over (sur, hyper), living-on, a supplement of life that is better than life and better than death, better than truth > la Chose par excellence: sur-vérité [see pp. 137-38 la sur-vérité du survivre][Blanchot calls la Chose the event]
the minute of living-on has the syntax of a revolution
my necessary immodesty
my necessary immodesty
Derrida says this against Nietzsche: triumph over oneself is also a pursuit of power (Gewalt)

motif.title: BEYOND ECONOMY / SURPLUS VALUE / GENERAL ECONOMY

content: writing is triumph, manic life-after-life insurance, indiscreet, exhibitionistic, even if  we read no “that’s me there” in it (this increase in discretion is more surplus-value of triumph), supplement of triumph, enough to make you sick

motif.title: BEYOND ECONOMY / SURPLUS VALUE / GENERAL ECONOMY

content: everything that preserves the dead: sculpture, mask, embalm
“the initial [re: J.] keeps (garde) the secret like a grave—jealously”

motif.title: UNSCATHED / SAFE / SACRED / GUARD / SECURITY / KEEP

content: Glas, apocalyptic text, revelation through faulty teletype [Apokalupsis Ioannou, the Revelation of St. John the Divine] [p. ~164 translators refer to end of my apocalypse (Glas)]
sur-vive: absolute event
call (demand, order, desire); btwn the call & the resurrection, there’s no time > absolute event, not effect of a cause, the cause, causa, la Chose, first name itself
call (demand, order, desire), “come”-effect of “first name” transcends all categories, thus strictly can be called transcendental, quī transcendit omne genus
apocalyptic, in other words capital unveiling [from GLAS]
seeing the terrible Chose, not as something, but as seeing itself
je m’arrête > “same interdiction encrypts the resurrection at the moment when he sees the terrible Chose”
all interdictions of pas, its double bind and invagination, make it possible to read the unreadability of impossible event, (the after-life of resurrection) of this “news”
in one’s most mournful glory: “turn oneself into a mouthful,” swallow oneself so as to be close to oneself, absolute knowledge [this is from GLAS]
witness, martyr, clue
[3 options re: relation btwn Blanchot’s L’arrêt de mort and the Gospels] 1) Gospel as paradigm 2) récit as paradigm (of Gospel) 3) seriality w/out paradigm [cf. GLAS]
mother as figure w/out figure

yes to yes w/out self-recollection, the must not or need not know yourself, the interdiction of each event, interposes an unconscious between the event and the experience of it, between living-on and presence
terribleness of la chose, not only ineffable, unnarratable: it’s interdictory, it forbids telling/seeing
joy of affirming endlessly
interdiction violated by itself, sets in motion a single pas, overflows impossible récit, that which forbids happens [French? arriver?]
more-than-life (sur-vie) marks a reprieve, excess triumphs over life, worth more than eternity of life but presents itself before the arrêt de mort
[interdiction as desire?] what remains beyond its reach is precisely what revives it at every moment
fragment as insaturable context
fragment as insaturable context
living on is neither opposite nor identical to living, difference is undecided, évasé like a bevelled edge (bord)

survivre delays at once life & death, line of least sure sur-, no clear-cut opposition, living on like differance, beyond identity & difference > tele-phone, tele-gram only 2 modes of this teleography in which trace, grapheme, does come secondarily but marks telic structure a priori
narrator is always away (at a distance, tele-)
differance: arrêt de mort or triumph of life
sur-vient, the event, Nietzsche’s Doppelgänger, ghosts, consists in nothing but coming about, being gone
apocalypse, eschatology, the “last War,” the “context” of l’arrêt de mort > “come” is said to event that comes about, apocalyptic superimprinting of texts
double invagination, through labor of translation, can be brought to bear on gaine in Glas [cf. GLAS p. 210 “against” Hegel, Marx, and Freud on subject of fetishism]
postponement
no paradigmatic text, only cryptic haunting from mark to mark, no piece, no metonymy, no integral corpus, thus no fetishism
living on as phantom revenance (one who lives on is always a ghost), this is re-markable
La Chose takes place w/out having place [Introduction to Meta… & OG sent to Olivia]
living on establishes the supplement [is supplement 2nd?], in truth beyond truth (la sur-vérité), supplement of truth w/out truth
vitrifying structure of writing & desire > hymen (as syllepsis) and pane of glass; p. ~141 Blanchot: glass doesn’t use up what I enjoy, reads book behind pane of glass
[Levinas’ “saying,” still a metaphysics of presence?]
Blanchot on watching “her” approach a truth “compared to which mine lost all interest”
[like the 2 columns in Glas] Blanchot’s narrative held together w/ invisible hinge, double inner edge (bord)
will they translate verre and vitre w/ glas? [funny]
legal bindings, framings, of Blanchot’s L’arrêt de mort into single book by single author

will they translate verre and vitre w/ glas? something else that escapes usage, use-value, the wearing away of what’s out of use, surplus-value and process of fetishization,“under-glass” quality of text in translation, of every mark, how can a translation be signed? [H p. 85 law of hospitality “under glass”]
how can a translation be signed?
fundamental irresponsibility for a translated text
MOP uses a logic of truth as presentation substituted for a logic of truth as representative equivalence [FL p. 282]
we always ask to be forgiven when we write
translation as transference, transference is love, one text loves the other in translation
performance w/out presence, takes place placelessly, the “-less” or “without,” and the pas, w/out pas, w/out negativity of pas

commitment [wedding proposal] in irresponsibility of speech [Blanchot’s character proposes in Slavic not French], arrêt of commitment, commitment thus arrêté, both in one’s language & the other’s—the hymen > mother tongue does away w/ commitment & seals it
I am “irresponsible” and absolutely committed in the establishment of the language of the other, which I do as if the first moment, the “at once” is the occasion of the hymen, its chance and its law
[trace as commitment to the other, the forgotten remnant in translation]
commitment only in the language of the other [see pp. 153-54], there is “language of the other” whenever there is a speech-event, this is what I mean by a “trace”
madness of understanding “yes”
madness of understanding “yes”

the violence of leaving a text alone, “one should refrain from” as law of text, qui se donne à lire, matched by another violence, exerted against first law in an attempt to commit to it, to draw close > violent truth of “reading” [don’t touch, shred to pieces]
letting trace involve or commit me in linguistic expropriation, do I break w/ maternal, mother tongue or w/ paternal law that kept me from mother?

[reference to la double séance] hymen s’arrête, comes about and is immediately forbidden, double-bind structure of event, its “madness”, every hymen intervenes like a crime, event, coup, its dissemination dissolves or absolves it in crowd by multiplying it incalculably
absolute crypt [heart] is unreadability—yet calls for infinite finite analysis, infinite-finite reada-translata-bility
essential irresponsibility of promise or response: crime of hymen  > repeats itself endlessly, takes place w/out taking place [writing/reading]
for intérieur (“conscience,” “inner tribunal,” “heart of hearts”) , crypt
Blanchot: “in the very heart of which lives the infinite”
how do we let a text live? letting someone read is like letting them live [re: Derrida pointing us toward Blanchot]
crypt, heart, hymen (chambers of desire)

“come”: single word, yet intertwined in series, inscribes its own effacement in middle of and on invaginated boundaries of récit, of these crypts, death or bridal chambers, hymen brings alliance & separation [after theft of key]
embalm, fetish

embalm [fetish?], set about the arrêt de mort in its double triumph: effigy, chambers of this desire in a sort of “funeral home” > [Blanchot’s narrator] loves them dead, he loves (by) seeing them dead
narrative affect of bottomless sorrow is allied w/ strange, insignificant coldness: mourning beyond measure
there’s an arrêt btwn 2 deaths [in L’arrêt de mort], thus hypertopia [see p. 140]
interruption, connectionless connection of arrêt > passes through insides w/out insides of ego of récitant
desire in a glass coffin [see SPOM p. 142 revolution shatters death masks in glass caskets]
double hymen w/ each woman; each woman double, death mask, cast, ghost, body at once living & dead, of other > utterly other “in relation to” one another: each one is the other
hymen is an “immediately” that weds symbiosis to synthanatosis (in a triumph w/out identity) [is the hymen not a fetish? embalm? encrypt? the at once of disavowal? cf. GLAS p. 210]

hymen, double bind, double affirmation, yes, yes, come, come [re: Blanchot’s 2 ghostly fiancées in L’arrêt de mort] signifies, desires, arrête life death, the life the death of the other, the other lives and dies > “for there is an other of the other and it is not the same” [see POO p. 11 “other of the other” is the very undeniable of ethics]
hymen is a “double bind” because each of these bonds that bind is [?], in itself, double
X of L’arrêt de mort, ichthus, (see +R), fish out of water, Christ-like figure of “who,” resurrection [see p. 168 raising an X, chi, chiasma over him]
arrêt w/out Aufhebung
arrêt w/out Aufhebung
Miss Blind feminist objects to Derrida’s mad hypothesis re: hymen

“and” as arrêt de mort, “and” of double bind, and I say “come,” “and immediately"-writing, annihilates time in ring of eternal return, yokes affirmation to itself in récit, the being-at-the-same-time of the other beyond time
the passivity of “letting” is different from the passivity of couples and pairs (e.g. pair active/passive)
story of the woman [Miss Blind feminist] who wouldn’t let Derrida have his “mad hypothesis”  [2 women approaching via hymen w/out narrator: absolute terror]
terrifying affirmation of one hymen guards the terror of another
pursue oneself by using one terror to avoid the other [neurosis?] [Abraham, more than one fidelity]

in Blanchot’s L’arrêt de mort, 2 women, 2 voices w/out voice, tele-phone each other: “come” > how do we read this unreadable hymen? it takes place as unreadable, from bottom of crypt in which it remains > it will have taken place where it remains: that’s the proof

Derrida’s mad hypothesis, nothing to do w/ intention of “author” that the hymen btwn the 2 women in L’arrêt de mort (separated by uncrossable glass partition of 2 stories) is the absolute terror, that they love and approach each other w/out the narrator
mad hypothesis overruns oppositional values that make rules and form the law in all the schools of reading, overruns delimitation of the fantasy as well
everything took place as if narrator desired that the 2 women resembled each other > in accordance w/ hymen (pas w/out him)
matter of economy (time, space, counting words, signs, marks) arrests translations
economy: stricture not coupure [pre-capitalist machine?], always external constraint that arrests a text in general, i.e. anything, for example life death
what is arrested here: authenticity (Eigentlichkeit) of a being-for-death

think exteriority from angle of economy of the arrêt: greatest “bound” energy, bandée, tightly gathered around its own limit (Hemmung, Haltung) > immediately disseminated, sand, empty, unloaded, spontaneously: in trance of trans, ghosts, transes, folies du jour (cf. Glas on trépas, trans/partition [Derrida’s referring to Genet crossing national borderlines])
arrêt de mort brings about the arrêt of the law
ex. of Derrida’s “radiant narcissism”
Derrida did not keep his promise to consider translatability [see p. ~89], but keeps a secret
to speak of writing, triumph, as living on, is to denounce [Freud’s] manic fantasy (not w/out repeating it)
